questions.text: Match the following terms with their correct definitions: 1. Subclinical case a. The first case of a disease identified in a group or population 2. Primary case b. A person who contracts the disease directly from the primary case. 3. Secondary case c. A person who exhibits mild or no symptoms but is still infected 4. Index case d. The first case that comes to the attention of health authorities

A 6-year-old child visits the pediatric clinic with a high fever, cough, runny nose, and conjunctivitis. Three days later, the child develops a distinctive maculopapular rash that begins on the face and spreads to the rest of the body. The oral pharyngeal examination is shown below. During what period is this child most likely contagious and should be isolated to prevent transmission to others?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-2 days before to 4-5 days after the appearance of rash

options.label: B
options.text: 4-6 days before symptoms to 7 days thereafter

options.label: C
options.text: From 4 days before to 4 days after rash onset.

options.label: D
options.text: 7 days before symptoms to 7 days after the appearance of the r

questions.correct_answer: C. From 4 days before to 4 days after rash onset.
questions.explanation:
Disease

Period of communicability

Measles

4 days before to 4 days after the rash appearance (Option C)

Chickenpox

1-2 days before to 4-5 days after the appearance of rash (Option A)

Mumps

4-6 days before symptoms to 7 days thereafter (Option B)

Rubella

7 days before symptoms to 7 days after the appearance of the rash (Option D)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the community health centre with a fever, malaise, and an itchy, vesicular rash (shown in the image below) that began two days ago. The child's mother asks when it will be safe for her child to return to school without posing a risk of spreading the infection to other children. What is the appropriate advice regarding the duration of isolation for this child to prevent the spread of this infection?
questions.correct_answer: D. Until all lesions are crusted
questions.explanation:
Disease

Duration of isolation

Chickenpox

Until all lesions are crusted, usually 6 days after the onset of the rash. (Option D)

Measles

7 days after the onset of rash (Option A)

Diphtheria

Until 48 hrs of antibiotics or negative cultures after treatment (Option B)

Salmonellosis

Until 3 negative stool cultures (Option C)

Pertussis

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease

Mumps

Until swelling subsides

Tuberculosis

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy

Cholera

3 days after tetracycline started

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their typical incubation periods: 1. COVID-19 a. 18-72 hours 2. Typhoid b. 3-21 days 3. Influenza c. 10-14 days
questions.explanation:
Diseases

Incubation period

COVID-19

3-21 days

Typhoid

10-14 days

Influenza

18-72 hours

Measles

10-14 days

Mumps 

14-21 days

Rubella

2-3 weeks

Varicella

14-16 days

Hepatitis A

15 to 50 days

Hepatitis B

30 to 180 days

Hepatitis C

14 to 180 days

Hepatitis E

15 to 60 days

questions.text: During an outbreak of measles in a small community, a primary case was identified in a household of 6 people. Within the next two weeks, 4 additional household members developed measles. What is the secondary attack rate (SAR) for this household?
What specific measure does the term "secondary attack rate" refer to?

options.label: C
options.text: Number of deaths due to a disease.

questions.text: During a local polio outbreak, a routine health check reveals poliovirus in the stool of a 10-year-old boy who shows no symptoms of illness. He has been participating in community sports events. What type of carrier is this boy most likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Types of Carrier

Definition

Examples

Healthy (Asymptomatic)

Harbours and transmits a pathogen without showing symptoms.
  • Polio
  • Typhoid fever
  • COVID-19
  • Meningitis
  • Cholera

Incubatory 

(Option C ruled out)

 

Can transmit the disease during the incubation period before symptoms appear.
  • Measles
  • Influenza
  • Pertussis
  • Polio
  • Mumps

Convalescent (Option A ruled out)

 

Continues to harbour and shed the pathogen for a short period after recovering from acute illness.
  • Diphtheria
  • Meningococcal meningitis
  • Typhoid
  • Cholera

Chronic (Option D ruled out)

Harbours and excretes the pathogen for an extended period (often >1 year) after initial infection.
  • Hepatitis B
  • Typhoid fever
  • Malaria
  • Gonorrhoea

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the median incubation period?

options.label: A
options.text: Shortest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases

options.label: B
options.text: Longest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases

options.label: C
options.text: Average time from exposure to recovery in 50% of cases

options.label: D
options.text: Average time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases

questions.correct_answer: D. Average time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases
questions.explanation:
Diseases

Incubation period

COVID-19

3-21 days

Typhoid

10-14 days

Influenza

18-72 hours

Measles

10-14 days

Mumps

14-21 days

Rubella

2-3 weeks

Varicella

14-16 days

Hepatitis A

15 to 50 days

Hepatitis B

30 to 180 days

Hepatitis C

14 to 180 days

Hepatitis E

15 to 60 days

questions.text: Match the following terms with their correct definitions: 1.Serial Interval a. The time from infection to the onset of symptoms. 2.Incubation Period b. The time between the onset of symptoms in a primary case and the onset of symptoms in secondary cases. 3.Window Period c. The time between infection and when the pathogen can be detected by laboratory tests. 4.Generation Time d. The time from infection in a new host to the onset of symptoms in that new host.
Which of the following statements best describes the difference between a carrier state and a latency period?

options.label: A
options.text: Carrier state: Symptomatic Latency period: Asymptomatic

options.label: B
options.text: Carrier state: Pathogen transmissible, even asymptomatic. Latency period: Pathogen dormant, not transmissible

options.label: C
options.text: Carrier state: Time before initial exposure to the pathogen Latency period: Time before symptoms appear.

options.label: D
options.text: Carrier state: Occurs when the person is recovering from the disease. Latency period: Occurs after symptoms have resolved

questions.correct_answer: B. Carrier state: Pathogen transmissible, even asymptomatic. Latency period: Pathogen dormant, not transmissible
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Carrier State

Latency Period

Pathogen Activity

The pathogen is present and active.

The pathogen is present but dormant.

Symptoms

No symptoms were shown by the person.

Transmissibility

The pathogen is transmissible to others.

Pathogen is not transmissible.

Stage in Disease Course

It can occur after recovery or without any disease phase.

Typically, it occurs between the initial infection and the onset of symptoms.

Detection

Pathogens can be detected through tests.

Pathogens may not be easily detectable.

questions.text: Match the appropriate answer: 1) Virulence a) Ability of the pathogen to cause disease by producing toxins and evading host defenses 2) Infectivity b) Ability of the pathogen to enter, survive, and multiply in the host 3) Pathogenicity c) Ability of the pathogen to induce an immune response in the host 4) Antigenicity d) Ability of the pathogen to cause disease by invading tissues and producing toxins
The transfer of infectious agents within the vector from one stage of life to the next occurs in which type of transmission?
questions.explanation:
Transovarian transmission

(Vertical)

Transstadial transmission

(Horizontal)

Definition

Transfer of infectious agent from the mother vector to its progeny.

Transfer of infectious agent within the vector from one stage of life to another.

Examples

E.g., Kyasanur forest disease, scrub typhus, Q fever, and Rocky Mountain spotted fever.

E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease)

Larve gets infected, which develops into a nymph and, lastly, an infected adult.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male has had a fever of 103°F, chills, and severe headaches that have persisted for three days. A blood smear confirms the presence of Plasmodium falciparum trophozoites in erythrocytes. Which type of biological transmission does this parasite undergo within the vector?
questions.explanation:
Propagative transmission

The agent only multiplies in number within the vector.

E.g., Yersinia pestis in rat flea.

Cyclodevelopmental transmission

Agent develops into infective form within the vector without multiplying.

E.g.,Microfilaria in culex mosquito

Cyclopropagative transmission

Agent develops into infective form and multiplies in number within the vector.

E.g., Malarial parasite in Anopheles mosquito

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is spread via droplet nuclei?
questions.explanation:
Droplet

Droplet nuclei

Direct mode of transmission

Indirect mode of transmission

It can spread via contact with the oromucosal membrane, conjunctiva.

Enters the alveoli.

Heavier particles that are more than 5 microns in size

Lighter particles which are less than 5 microns in size

They fall on the ground due to gravity

They remain suspended in the air, and it can disseminate along with air currents

Can travel less than 1 meter in distance

(Up to 30-60 cm)

Can travel more than 1 meter in distance

Examples:

  • Common cold (Option C)
  • Diphtheria (Option B)
  • Whooping cough (Option A)
  • Tuberculosis
  • COVID-19
  • Meningococcal meningitis

Examples:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Influenza
  • Chickenpox
  • Measles
  • Q fever
  • COVID-19

DIRECT

INDIRECT

Droplet (30 to 60 cm spread)

Fomite

Transplacental

Airborne ( > 60 cm spread)

Contact

Vehicle Borne

Soil

Unclean hands
 

Vector borne

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman was screened for TORCH infections in her third trimester. Which of the following diseases is typically associated with vertical transmission during this trimester of pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Vertical transmission of diseases.

1st trimester

Rubella, Chickenpox/varicella

2nd trimester

Parvovirus

3rd trimester

Toxoplasmosis, CMV, Hepatitis B and Syphilis.

During delivery

HIV and herpes

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents with sudden onset fever and a rapidly enlarging tender lymph node in the left axilla. Considering the clinical history of plague, which of the following is not true regarding the vector responsible for transmission of this infection?

options.label: B
options.text: Pathogen undergoes development within the vector.

questions.explanation:
Mechanical vector

Biological vector

  • Infectious agent is mechanically transported on the feet or proboscis of the agent. (Option A)
  • It can also get passively excreted unchanged from the agent GIT. (Option D)

Infectious agents are taken up by the vector, where they can undergo a necessary development cycle. (Option B)

An agent does not undergo multiplication or development within the vector.

E.g., the spread of bacillary dysentery by houseflies.

Agent undergoes

  • Multiplication (propagative) - plague bacilli in fleas.
  • Development (cyclo-developmental) - microfilariae in culex mosquito.
  • Both (cyclo-propagative) - malaria parasites in Anopheles.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases exclusively involves obligate hosts in its transmission cycle?
Which of the following diseases are seen in the transmission cycle of dead-end hosts?
Which of the following correctly identifies the primary and secondary hosts?

options.label: A
options.text: Malaria: Primary Host - Mosquitoes, Secondary Host - Humans

options.label: B
options.text: Filaria: Primary Host - Humans, Secondary Host - Mosquitoes(Anopheles)

options.label: C
options.text: Dengue: Primary Host - Ticks, Secondary Host - Humans

options.label: D
options.text: Chikungunya: Primary Host - Humans, Secondary Host - Ticks

questions.correct_answer: A. Malaria: Primary Host - Mosquitoes, Secondary Host - Humans
questions.explanation:
Primary Host

Secondary Host

Definition
  • The organism in which the parasite reaches maturity.
  • Agent reproduces sexually in the primary host.
  • The organism in which the parasite lives for a shorter period, often as an intermediate stage.
  • There is no sexual maturation of the agent in the secondary agent.

Examples

Malaria

Mosquitoes (Anopheles species)

Humans

Filaria

Humans

Mosquitoes

Dengue

Mosquitoes (Aedes species)

Humans

Chikungunya

Humans

Mosquitoes (Aedes species)

questions.text: Which of the following correctly pairs the disease with its primary reservoir and source of infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Disease: Measles, Reservoir: Humans, Source of Infection: Respiratory droplets

options.label: B
options.text: Disease: Plague, Reservoir: Soil, Source of Infection: Contaminated wounds

options.label: C
options.text: Disease: Tetanus, Reservoir: Humans, Source of Infection: Mosquito bites

options.label: D
options.text: Disease: Malaria, Reservoir: Wild rodents, Source of Infection: Flea bites

questions.correct_answer: A. Disease: Measles, Reservoir: Humans, Source of Infection: Respiratory droplets
questions.explanation:
Disease

Reservoir

Source of Infection

TB





 

Humans

Respiratory droplets.

HIV

Blood, sexual contact, mother-to-child.

Typhoid

Contaminated food and water.

Measles (Option A)

Respiratory droplets.

Malaria (Option D)

Mosquito bites (Anopheles species).

Cholera

Contaminated water and food.

KFD (Kyasanur Forest Disease)

Small mammals, monkeys

Tick bites.

Tetanus (Option C)

Soil

Plague (Option B)

Wild rodents (e.g., rats)

Flea bites.

JE (Japanese Encephalitis)

Pigs, wild birds

Mosquito bites (Culex species).
